subject: Programming
title: LISP and Artificial Intelligence
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: LISP and Artificial Intelligence.

hook.text: In 1958, John McCarthy wanted a language that could reason about its own code.

buildup.text: He invented LISP, built on mathematical functions instead of step-by-step commands.

discovery.text: LISP could modify itself while running. Programs could rewrite their own logic on the fly.

twist.text: AI researchers loved it, but LISP was too slow for mainstream use and stayed niche.

climax.text: Today's functional programming revival traces directly back to LISP's 1958 ideas.

quiz.question: What unique ability did LISP have?
options: It could modify itself while running
